I had a weird and frustrating experience setting up this thing. During initial phase, after choosing language, the HDMI channel keep changing as soon as I press the ok button. Afterwards, it scan for network. Out of the box, this thing is crap!!! It will not allow to give me a chance to enter the Roku device  password and keeps cycling back to scan network. I had Roku for years and my older one crashed few days ago. Bought a new one, and still had a frustrating experience just with set up. I have Xfinity wifi which I connect all my previous Roku. My other device worked with Xfinity wifi, but recently the Roku kept acting up when I connect. Roku customer service is non existent even if you have a Roku account for years. I'm done with these streaming devices. I'm getting by connecting my Chromebook to hdmi and watch on my big screen TV whatever I'm watching on my laptop, old fashion way.

Activation should have been easy but I mistakenly tried to use a credit  card I thought I had activated but according to the bank I didn't.  When I used the live chat at the roku activation  site to get help, the rep rapidly sent long litinies pushing 3 kinds of upgrades.  She typed so fast and the screen moved before i had time to read.  After I told her I wasn't interested in any upgrade, she left our chat without giving me any help.  However I was able to activate once I used a valid credit card without any hickuop.Now the product itself.  Roku has lots of chanels and shows.  More than enough for an average TV watcher like me. It's HD quality  is excellent.  My Samsung smart TV never looked this good.  Navigation has been easy.

I have 2 Samsung Smart Tvs that are a few years old.  After a while Samsung stopped supporting alot of the apps and little by little deleted them from their interface.  In addition alot of the new apps don't work well with Samsung's interface.  A Customer Svc Rep for one of the apps that I called for assistance recommended Roku and I ended up buying a kit for each TV.  Very easy to set up, easy to add apps and easy to use.  There is NO SETUP FEE. Whoever wrote that in their review is lying.  In addition to apps that you need to pay a monthly fee for, there are also several apps that offer free programming with commercials.  Ive used streamers before there were smart tvs, and Roku is by far the best Ive ever used.  Highly recommend it to turn your older smart tv into a smarter device.

Basically wanted to replace my xfinity small TV adaptors that I was being charged monthly for. I purchased two of these items, these are good for my non 4k TV's and have support for resolution to 1080p.These items were very easy to set up and say faster than my older Roku device from 2015. It really was night and day in terms of speed.

Before you buy another Roku product please investigate the failure of both their Engineering and Customer Service departments.Roku customers have frequently received faulty software updates and customer service is usually unable or unwilling to help. As an example a recently released software update (version 9.3) caused many streaming devices (and TVs) to have their WiFi connections crippled or disabled. To further the damage, Customer Service provided no useful support. In fact, recently they are refusing to support the devices that were harmed.

It's easy to just buy the cheapest Roku, figuring who needs lots of extras. In the past I've bought one or two up from the cheapest. Then Roku sent me an email offer, my current device was about to be obsolete, take them now up on a limited time offer of a new device for only $15. No details. Dear reader, I was foolish and took it.The old device had an on-off button to control the TV, and a volume control as well. This cheapo has neither. I've gone back to needing to keep both the tv remote and Roku piecacrap on hand, since I frequently change volume and pause, rewind, etc.

I got this specifically for Disney+ since it isn't on my "Smart" TV.  Figured it was a logical move.  It was working great until 5-10 minutes into any show it loses it's Internet connection.  Everything else in my house still works, but not the Roku.  It is also right next to my modem/router and often it will let me reconnect right away.I used to be a big fan of Roku, but this has been a horrible experience.

ROKU worked great until recent firmware update. Now there is a HDCP HDMI incompatiblity error for about 20 seconds before watching content, and when it eventually plays the content there is crackling in the audio. Of course I checked the cable and TV with my BluRay Player, and everything works fine there. I bought different HDMI cable too. There is no solution provided, but unplugging all cables, and restarting. That didn't work. On their website they say that one has to have a HDCP compatible device. Granted my TV is 15 years old, that is probably the issue. If they are pushing people to buy new TVs, that would be a good reason for a bad review. You may have different information, but for now I need to leave a bad review.UPDATE: I have bought HDMI switch, which solved this problem.... I just don't think most people will figure it out, unless they do some research.

Do not buy the Roku Express if you stream HULU!!  HULU did an update to their system end of May or so, and the Roku Express has several problems streaming HULU.  Several have complained on the Roku "Community Page", because that is the only way you can discuss issues with your Roku.  You never can speak or even have a chat on a chat box with an actually person.  Everything are bots.  I have 3 of these and my TV will not stream Hulu consistently for 5 minutes.  It's been almost 3 months since the issue started with no resolution.  Just that they are "working on it."

I recently upgraded my cell subscription and it includes HBO MAX. As my sister is on my cell account I sent her this new Roku Express... Yes, without checking, and then find out it doesn't play or have the ability to download HBO MAX APP. You can get old regular HBO content but not MAX. So it's worthless for that purpose and that was all she cared about. Be Aware! I personally have a Roku III and IV unit and always liked them but they don't support HBO MAX either but my TV did so I never checked about the Roku.

Not bad - it came free with Sling. It lasted about a year and then it states that our WI FI signal is poor. My Laptop about 7 feet away states that the signal is excellent, but this box states that it is "poor". I think the internal antenna is...not good. It is too bad that there is not an option to install a small external antenna to beef it up a bit.

I have three Roku Express devices purchased in May 2019. A couple of months ago they started loosing sound and required a power cycle to get the sound to come back. Looking at Roku's customer pages, hundreds of others have this same problem and Roku's only response is to power cycle the unit. I do not recommend purchasing anything Roku as customer support is non-existent.

Overheats.  Modem shuts down and I have to boot it.  I don’t think I watch excessive tv and we’re not gamers.  I tried the stick and it overheated in ten minutes.  Space in question is reasonably ventilated.

This worked for a few weeks. After replacing my router, could not connect again. There is no customer support on the Roku site; you must ask the "community" questions. But you can't ask until you verify that your question hasn't already been asked. So buy a Roku, and you are on your own, basically, if there are any issues.

Compared to every other model this is absolutely crap. It’s crazy glitchy. It’s always struggling to stay connected. Today it just decided to stop working altogether. I had to reset the whole device and set it up from scratch, which took over half an hour.It’s not my internet. My other Roku never gives me any trouble, and it’s at least 5 years old now.

We bought two of these because we wanted to dump DirecTV and save on our outrageous satellite bill. It was easy to create an account and hook it up to the wifi. Now we can stream Netflix, Prime, YouTube, Hulu, and Disney+. We ended up signing up for another streaming service (Spectrum TV) and this worked super well with it  - we just had to download the app which took all of 20 seconds. Apparently Fire TV will not allow users to access the Spectrum app, so the Roku was a much better choice for our needs. One thing - this little box must have a direct line to the remote or it won't read it. Be sure to position it where you can get the remote pointed right at the box.

I have to TV's in the house and ROKU is in both. I no longer have cable and don't miss it one bit. There are tons of free channels asking with subscription ones. I do subscribe to Amazon Prime, Netflix and Hulu but even with those three subscriptions the cost is no where near what we were paying for cable.ROKU Doors not charge an activation fee! If you're being asked to pay one you're in the wrong place! Try typing in the website exactly as printed, do not do a search for it!

We've had two Rokus in use since 2012, back when we gave up cable. Even though the boxes were a little laggy against 2019 software, they were still solid and I would have kept using them if support wasn't being phased out before the end of the year, per tech sites, and a reminder email from Roku itself. Additionally, the new Disney+ app wouldn't load; another sign to upgrade our heavily used Rokus to something with the latest Roku OS. I purchased two Express boxes, released in September (3930R). They're a perfect resolution match for our TVs, which are both 1080p. It's worth reading through the specs to avoid surprises: single band wireless, not a voice controlled remote, maximum output resolution is 1080p. All fine for our use--in fact, they were very much like the old boxes we were perfectly happy with, but now able to get the latest software updates. These new Rokus feel snappy--in and of themselves, I think, and because we'd been using 7 year old hardware! So pleased with this purchase: fantastic price, up-to-date software--looking forward to using them for years to come.

Personally, the way the world has been coming lately, more of us have been forced to stay at home with creature comforts. We as a country have stopped eating out, going to work because of the coronavirus, and felt more suppressed with self-doubt and hurt. But there are always things to watch on television or the internet, rather than just about depressing news. For that, it is more important now than ever to purchase a streaming device. I have used both Amazon's and Roku's streaming devices for years, but made the decision to go back to Roku, because of the convenience & quality. If you're into streaming online for the first time, you'll find a expressway to your boredom with this.The Roku Express+ Media Player is a simple and straight-forward way to connect you to streaming online, playing music and media for the first time, without problems. It is very easy to connect, small and compact. It is a plug & play device that works flawlessly with my TV while I watch my favorite services online like CBS All Access, popcorn flix and more recent entries like CBS All Access and HBO Now. The interface is easy to hookup, and works with any HDTV. Yet, there are a few faults here. For one, it doesn't work with the RCA audio/video hookup anymore, like the way it used to from the earlier Roku device. Also, you cannot have a way to burn your media onto another media recorder like a DVD recorder or VCR if you still have cassette tapes. So for those problems, you may have to result in purchasing other media players from Roku, or you may have to consider purchasing a converter box if you need to.

This is an inexpensive option for cord-cutters (kind of an oxymoron since it still has cords) i.e., those who are looking to ditch cable or satellite tv. It is basically a box that attaches to your tv via an HDMI cable, and then allows you to download various apps, some free, some paid (e.g., Netflix, Hulu, Disney+, Sling TV, YouTube TV, etc.) through which you can watch TV or movies.The setup is easy. You just plug the Roku box into one of the HDMI ports on your TV, then connect it via a USB cable to a power source, which can be either through a USB port in the TV or connect the USB end of the cable into a power adapter that plugs into a regular wall outlet. Then you just follow the on-screen prompts to set it up, which will include connecting to your home's wireless network, telling it what you like to watch so it can suggest apps to download, and either setting up or logging into your Roku account (if you have an account set up).

I already have an account with Sling and bought one of these devices (not from Amazon) hoping to free up my tablet for other uses. At the end of the quick setup booklet, it says that you have to setup a Roku account and give them a credit card for billing! Sling already bills me directly, so why would Roku demand a credit card from me? For what reason? That is totally stupid !! Roku's website FAQ's dont even address this issue and dont give you an email address to ask this question. 99.9% of FAQ's, and Roku is no exception here, only address lame questions like: Why doesnt the device change channels when I point the remote at my dog, but changes channels when I point it at my cat ?Never, Ever, once in the past 20yrs have I ever been able to find an answer to a question in the FAQ's !

I own 3 of these now.  I first bought one for my TV that I hadn't used in 7 years but I dusted off because of COVID-19 but I didn't like the tinny sound from the speakers so I upgraded to a Roku Sound Bar and gave this one to my mother.It is simple, easy-to-use and has endless options for entertainment.  There are so many channels available it boggles the mind and the entertainment is endless but there simply just isn't enough time in the day to view everything that is available on all the channels you could possibly watch!  Netflix, Hulu, Prime Video, Disney, HBO, CBS, Apple TV, man oh man alive it goes on and on and on plus all the specialty channels... I don't know what else to say.  The quality of the picture is top-notch on any modern TV and you only need to upgrade to a better Roku if you have a 4K TV, otherwise this is just fine for most people's needs.

When I first bought the Roku Express it worked great - the remote that comes included was snappy, has convenient shortcut buttons to streaming services I use, and could be programmed to control basic functions of my TV like power and volume.  Similarly, streaming quality was great, the user interface was simple and effective, and all around it was a great product.Fast forward to 3-4 months shy of 2 years later however and the dependability/quality of the Roku has dropped significantly.  Beginning a few months ago the remote began not always registering roku-specfic actions for a short while after powering on the TV/Roku (things like navigation, 'Ok', 'play/pause', etc.) - I would have to wait a minute or two for the remote to begin working. It wasn't a huge deal since Roku also has an accompanying app that serves as a virtual remote control I could fall back on.

the setup could have been easier, maybe i did something wrong, but then again ive messed up setups in the past and still i didnt do as much backing and forthing from a phone to a tv, ever!! in my life until this. if it asks you to be all anal about creating a pin for purchases, because you are worried your kids will buy stuff, listen to me and skip for now, and change the setting after you download everything you need. i tried creating a pin on my phone and it would come up invalid on mu tv when i typed it in. backing and forthing , resetting the roku, it was just such a hastle i didnt expect, or wanted. still its a coo lil device.

The Roku Express is a decent streaming device that might satisfy your needs.  It is cheap (found last year's model on sale for only $17!) and the Roku user interface is great.  Easy to setup.  Some limitations to keep in mind: this is a 1080p device, so not for 4k TV's.  Also, it only operates on the 2.4 ghz wifi network.  If you live in apartments with lots of competing wifi networks good luck getting a steady signal.  The hardware in the express is not great at picking up wifi at a distance in comparison with other wifi devices like iPads or smartphones.  One more limitation that affects all Rokus (not just the express) is that most of the content is not in 5.1 surround sound.  Vudu and Amazon have 5.1 surround, but other popular favorites like Pluto TV, the Roku Channel, and Sony Crackle do not.  Overall, I think Amazon reviewers have overrated the Express.  The average user would be better off with the Streaming Stick Plus.  The latter has 4k and 5 ghz wifi support along with a better remote.  It is about twice the price though.

We love our Roku Express and purchasing it through Amazon has been 💯better than from a box store! We had one before but it burned up in a wild fire along with everything else we all owned. Finally we decided to purchase another one, and it was 10$ cheaper than how much it would have cost us at the store. It came quickly as usual with our Prime! No complaints there! We were just using the Xbox to stream but that becomes a pain after a while. Roku is so much better and all the apps are up to date, so even if your TV is older and NOT SMART you can easily add the ROKU EXPRESS and stream pretty much anything you want! Hulu my personal favorite or Netflix etc. We Also use other apps like WWE Network through our Roku as well. I’m not even sure I even know all of the apps that it comes with. I do know there also is a bunch of free channels it has preloaded on the box too. I don’t watch a ton of TV so I don’t really know all of it’s capabilities, I just know it works well and doesn’t glitch out and the picture is super clear. The remote is tiny, I loose it all the time, but it works so it’s fine. I want to say there is a phone app you can download to use as a remote but then again I’m not completely 💯sure. No issues with buffering or lagging either. It’s really easy to figure out too. Definitely recommend this streaming device to anyone looking for a quality product for a reasonable price, all you need is an internet connection and a TV of course and you will be good to go!

I've seen some people in the reviews saying that they had to pay again once they bought it, and they are wrong, at least according to my experience. This device is literally plug and play. Once you plug it in, you're greeted with a screen that tells you to log in and basically just set everything up. Once that is done, get ready for probably the best tv experience you'll ever have. The remote is quick and snappy, the user interface is fantastic (10/10). Overall, Roku really nailed it on everything from hardware to the user experience.

I love my Roku!! The only problem I had was trying to hook it up to my TV as I hooked everything up the HDMI to USB the way it was supposed to and couldn't figure out why it wasn't working. I was very frustrated at this point because it wasn't connecting so I stepped away for about an hour and thought let me check the batteries in the remote control, that was my exact problem! The batteries that came with it did not work hence my giving the remote three stars! It was frustrating but it was figured out in the end. Going forward anybody ordering the Roku Express make sure that you have a set of AAA batteries at home in case yours won't pair that may be the problem!

Ordered a Roku Express, and it worked well initially, but then failed and needed to be replaced.  That happens, so just unlucky, but thats where the real headaches begin.  You can't call Roku support during the pandemic.  Not sure why, but thats how they are operating.  They dont provide a quick and easy way to chat or email them from their support website, and they make it very difficult to contact them and to determine how to deal with a defective product.  Eventually, I logged in on the support site, and there we finally found a way to tell the about our defective unit.  They responded with an email saying they will replace it, shipping out a new one when they receive the defective one, but they dont include a shipping address.  The email contains a link to an article on their website which also doesnt provide a shipping address.  Followed up with another email to Roku, and they said they would forward our email to another department to get us a shipping address.  We are still going through this back and forth with them.  I havent seen such terrible product support in a very long time.  Its almost as if they are trying to make it as difficult as possible for you to deal with a defective product.  So, great product as long as you dont get a defect, then the support really is awful.
